p: Yeh Lam received a B.Sc. in Mathematics from Peking University, a M.Sc. in Statistics from Imperial College of Science and Technology, and a Ph.D. in Operations Research from the University of Manchester. His research spectrum covers statistics, applied probability, and operations research. Professor Lam has published 70 articles in well-known journals including Journal of the American Statistical Association, Biometrika, The Annals of Statistics, Journal of the Applied Probability, Advances in Applied Probability, European Journal of Operational Research, and IEEE Transactions on Reliability. Recently, he also published a monograph “The Geometric Process and its Applications.” He is a member of the International Statistical Institute, and of the International Chinese Statistical Association. Because of his pioneering research into the theories and applications of Geometric Processes, in 2008, Professor Lam received the Second Prize (First Contributor) of the Natural Science Award of the Ministry of Education, China.

authors.name: Yeh Lam

details.abstract: A geometric process delta -shock maintenance model for a repairable system is introduced. If there exists no shock, the successive operating time of the system after repair will form a geometric process. Assume that the shocks will arrive according to a Poisson process. When the interarrival time of two successive shocks is smaller than a specified threshold, the system fails, and the latter shock is called a deadly shock. The successive threshold values are monotone geometric. The system will fail at the end of its operating time, or the arrival of a deadly shock, whichever occurs first. The consecutive repair time after failure will constitute a geometric process. A replacement policy N is adopted by which the system will be replaced by a new, identical one at the time following the N th failure. Then, for the deteriorating system, and the improving system, an optimal policy N* for minimizing the long-run average cost per unit time is determined analytically.

links.abstract: In the reliability literature, maintenance time is usually ignored during the optimization of maintenance policies. In some scenarios, costs due to system failures may vary with time, and the ignorance of maintenance time will lead to unrealistic results. This paper develops maintenance policies for such situations where the system under study operates iteratively at two successive states: up or down.
